item.title: The influence of translation ambiguity on bilinguals' reading in L1
item.description: This is a project I did with my supervisor Dr. Debra Jared at Western University and the RAs in our lab: Yae Ram Kim, Jia-Wei Shih, and Alexandra Sherwin. Backgrounds Translation ambiguity occurs when a word in one language has more than one translation in another language. For example, the English word bark means “dog bark” and “tree bark,” and they translate into distinct French words: aboie and écorce, respectively.
